questions.text: A 77-year-old male patient was admitted to the ICU for spikes of fever (103 -104°F). His history is significant for having hypertension and diabetes for 17 years and CKD stage 5 for one year. He was admitted 10 days before for an emergency dialysis via the central line. He was given antibiotics: vancomycin and amikacin in his last dialysis cycle, but the fever failed to subside. On Culture, the organism was found to be vancomycin resistant, catalase negative and Gram stain shows a Spectacle-eyed shape as shown in the figure. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given Gram stain picture shows Purple-stained, Round organisms, suggesting Gram-positive cocci.
  • Gram-positive cocci which show a catalase-negative test are in the Streptococcus family.
  • The presence of a characteristic Spectacle-eyed shape leads to a diagnosis of Enterococcus (gamma-hemolytic streptococcus).
  • Vancomycin resistance in enterococci has been increasingly reported nowadays.
  • VRE is mediated by the van gene, which alters the target site for vancomycin present in the cell wall; i.e. D-alanyl-D-alanine side chain of the peptidoglycan layer, which is the usual target site for vancomycin, is altered to D-alanyl-D-serine or D-alanyl-D-lactate.
  • These altered side chains have less affinity for binding to vancomycin.
  • Van gene has several genotypes, out of which van A and van B are common types, expressed by E. faecalis and more commonly by E. faecium.
  • E. faecalis and E. faecium are the two clinically important species. E. faecalis is the most common species isolated from clinical specimens, whereas E. faecium is more drug-resistant than E. faecalis.
  • Enterococci are one of the major healthcare-associated pathogens, producing various infections such as:
    • Urinary tract infections
    • Chronic prostatitis
    • Bacteremia and left-sided endocarditis involving mitral and aortic valves (common in intravenous drug abusers).
    • Intra-abdominal, pelvic and soft tissue infections, including surgical site infections following intra-abdominal surgeries.
    • Neonatal infections: Such as sepsis (mostly late-onset), bacteremia, meningitis, and pneumonia.

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus viridans (Option A): Streptococcus Viridans is Sensitive to Vancomycin and is usually present in chains on a Gram stain.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B), Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option C): The Staphylococcus family is catalase positive.

choices.text: Gown first → Mask or respirator → Goggles or face shield → Gloves
Gloves first → Face shield or goggles → Gown → Mask or respirator
Gown first → Goggles or face shield → Mask or respirator → Gloves
Gloves first → Gown → Goggles or face shield → Mask or respirator

questions.text: The correct order of donning a PPE kit is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In order to minimise the risk of transmission of infection, donning (wearing) and doffing (removing) of PPE must be performed in a particular sequence.

Steps of Donning (wearing)

  • Gown first → Mask or respirator → Goggles or face shield → Gloves.
  • Donning will be done from down to up when a man stands with his hands raised.

Steps of Doffing (removing)

  • Gloves first → Face shield or goggles → Gown → Mask or respirator.
  • Doffing is extremely important as even a minor breach in the doffing procedure would subject the health care worker to a huge risk of acquiring the infection.
  • All PPE should be removed just before exiting the patient room, except the respirator, which should be removed after leaving the patient room and closing the door.
  • Discard into the appropriate BMW bins:
    • Yellow bag: Gown/coverall, mask/respirator, shoe cover and cap
    • Red bag: Plastic apron, goggles/face shield, gloves.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Plasma sterilizers; 37-44°C; spores of bacillus stearothermophilus
Autoclave (steam sterilizer); 121-135°C; spores of geobacillus stearothermophilus
Ethylene oxide sterilizer; 55°C; Spores of Bacillus atrophaeus

questions.text: Identify the sterilant in the image, along with its corresponding temperature range and biological indicator.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shown here is of a Steam Steriliser / Autoclave.
  • It uses saturated steam under pressure to kill microorganisms (bacteria, viruses, spores) on medical/surgical equipment, laboratory tools, and other heat-resistant materials.
  • Temperatures of Autoclave: 121°C x 15 min x 15 psi (pounds square inch)
  • Control of Autoclave: Spores of "Bacillus stearothermophilus"
  • Autoclaving is done for:
    • Surgical instruments
    • All culture media except LJ & LSS media
    • Autoclavable plastic
    • Sputum samples before discarding
    • Surgical sutures except catgut

Explanation of other options:

Plasma sterilisers; 37-44°C; spores of Bacillus stearothermophilus (Option A): A plasma steriliser is a costly, latest method for sterilisation that uses hydrogen peroxide gas at low temperature with an electromagnetic field, and it effectively destroys Bacillus stearothermophilus spores.

Ethylene oxide steriliser; 55°C; Spores of Bacillus atrophaeus (Option C): The ethylene oxide steriliser uses ethylene oxide gas stored in liquid form, which acts as a high-level disinfectant.

Inspissation; 80-85°C; Spores of Bacillus atrophaeus (Option D):

Key takeaways:

questions.text: A 61-year-old person reactive to HIV, presented with altered mental status, seizures, neck stiffness, fever, photophobia and myalgia. On investigations, the CD4 count was 196/microliter. Negative staining was used for CSF specimens, which demonstrated refractile capsules around round budding yeast cells, and white mucoid colonies were obtained on SDA at 37°C. All of the following tests are used to confirm the likely organism except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history is suggestive of Meningitis, which, along with lab findings, suggests a diagnosis of Cryptococcal Meningitis. MALDI-TOF is not a confirmatory test for Cryptococcus.

MALDI-TOF

  • Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionisation - Time of Flight (MALDI-TOF) is a mass spectrometry-based technique used for identifying microorganisms based on their protein profiles.
  • It is a powerful tool that can be used for identifying fungal and bacterial pathogens, including Cryptococcus, but it is not used as a first-line test for cryptococcal diagnosis, and it is generally used as an adjunct rather than the primary confirmatory test.

Standard confirmatory tests for Cryptococcus include:

  • Direct detection methods:
    • Modified India ink stain / Nigrosin stain (Negative stain):- Appears as a refractile, delineated, clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells against a black background.
    • Gram stain:- show gram-positive, round, budding yeast cells
    • Mucicarmine stain:- It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans
    • Masson-Fontana stain:- It demonstrates the production of melanin
    • Alcian blue stain to demonstrate the capsule.
    • Latex agglutination test for capsular antigen
  • Culture methods:
    • Sabouraud's Dextrose agar
    • Niger seed agar / Bird seed agar
  • Urease test

questions.text: A HIV positive female presents with complaints of fever and shortness of breath for 4 days. On a CT scan of the lungs, ground-glass opacities are found. Histopathological examination of lung tissue obtained by bronchoscopy shows the following result. Identify the etiological agent in this patient.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The photo shows ping pong balls on methenamine silver stain, which indicates the aetiology to be Pneumocystis jirovecii, along with ground glass opacities on CT, and HIV being a risk factor.
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia has been increasingly reported after the discovery of HIV/AIDS.
  • Histopathological examination of lung tissue or fluids obtained by bronchoscopy, bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL), or open lung biopsy reveals cysts.
  • Gomori's methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts are stained black and appear crescent-shaped or like crushed ping-pong balls, against the green background.
  • Pneumocystis is not cultivable, and there is no serological test available.
  • Radiology: Chest X-ray depicts the classical finding of bilateral diffuse infiltrates. CT of the lung may reveal ground-glass opacities at the early stage.

Explanation of other options:

Aspergillus fumigatus (Option B): A. fumigatus is identified by acute angled branching hyphae, which are septate.

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option C): Cryptococcus neoformans on India ink staining, it shows round budding yeast cells with clear refractile capsules surrounding them (arrow).

Rhizopus (Option D): Rhizopus species are identified by right-angled hyphae, which are not septate.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female complains of recurrent episodes of nasal congestion, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for a year. On examination, the patient has a normal nasal septum, and multiple ethmoidal polyps are present. A tissue biopsy was taken and sent to the microbiology department for culture. The results on SDA medium and Microscopy are shown in the images, respectively. The organism was positive for Galactomannan antigen and Beta-D Glucan. Identify the causative organism in this patient.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history is suggestive of Fungal rhinosinusitis.

Cultures on SDA show smoky green, velvety to powdery colonies and on microscopy, conical-shaped vesicles and conidia are arising from the upper third of the vesicle, suggestive of Aspergillus Fumigatus.


Explanation of other options:

Rhizopus (Option D): On microscopy, Rhizopus is identified with right-angled aseptate hyphae.

choices.text: It is a normal reaction after giving the polio vaccine and resolves with time

questions.text: A 9-week-old baby was brought to the casualty with weakness in her right leg. On examination, her right leg appeared flaccid, and no deep tendon reflex could be elicited, although sensation was intact. The tone, movement, sensation, and reflexes of her other limbs were normal. Her immunisation records were up-to-date. CSF shows elevated protein with normal glucose levels. Faecal samples were collected and then sent to the referral centre, where the poliovirus was identified as a vaccine strain (not the 'wild-type' strain) of poliovirus type-1 was isolated. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario and Lab findings are suggestive of Vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis.

Vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP):

  • VAPP denotes all the cases of paralytic poliomyelitis that occur following OPV administration.
  • VAPP strains are OPV-like isolates, which show limited genetic divergence from their parental OPV strains (<1%).
  • VAPP is distinguished by the absence of loss of sensation and reflexes.
  • VAPP can occur among OPV recipients as well as their close contacts due to feco-oral spread.
  • However, VAPP strains are not capable of circulating in the community and do not cause outbreaks..
  • The most common serotype associated with VAPP is Sabin type 3 (60%), followed by Sabin type 2 (40%).

Vaccine-derived polioviruses (VDPVs):

  • The live-attenuated vaccine strains present in the oral polio vaccine may undergo genetic changes to become VDPV, thus being identified as the Wild strain. (Option B ruled out)
  • VDPV is capable of producing poliomyelitis; clinically indistinguishable from wild polioviruses (due to regain of neurovirulence).
  • Three types of VDPVs have been recognised, out of which circulating VDPVs (cVDPVs) are the most common type. The other two varieties are immunodeficiency-associated VDPVs (iVDPVs) and ambiguous VDPVs (aVDPVs).
  • cVdpV: These strains can circulate in the community, spread person-to-person by feco-oral transmission and can cause outbreaks.
  • The majority (90%) of cVDPV cases are due to Sabin type 2, followed by type 1.

Explanation of other options:

Poliomyelitis (Option C): Considering that the newborn is immunised to date, the occurrence of wild-strain poliomyelitis is unlikely.

It is a normal reaction after giving the polio vaccine and resolves with time (Option D): Normal vaccination is not associated with any clinical features, and emergence of any such signs should be evaluated promptly and thoroughly (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: All of the following are transmission cycles of Japanese Encephalitis except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Man is a dead-end host for Japanese Encephalitis. So no such transmission cycles exist.
  • Japanese Encephalitis virus is the leading cause of vaccine-preventable viral encephalitis in Asia, including India.
  • It belongs to the family Flaviviridae. It is an enveloped virus, containing ssRNA.
  • JE virus infects several non-human hosts, e.g. animals and birds.
  • Two transmission cycles are predominant.

Primary Transmission Cycle:

  • Enzootic Cycle (Pigs/Birds → Mosquitoes → Pigs/Birds)
  • Amplifying Hosts (High Viremia):
    • Pigs (Major amplifying host - develop high viral load)
    • Ardeid birds (Herons, egrets - natural reservoirs)
  • Vector: Culex mosquitoes (Mainly Culex tritaeniorhynchus)
  • Cycle: Mosquitoes bite infected pigs/birds → Virus replicates in mosquito → Mosquitoes transmit to new pigs/birds.

Secondary Transmission cycle (Spillover to Humans & Other Animals)

  • Dead-End Hosts (No Further Transmission):
    • Humans
    • Horses
    • Cattle
  • These hosts do not develop sufficient viremia to re-infect mosquitoes.
  • No human-to-human/mosquito transmission.
  • Incubation Period: 5-15 days

Symptoms:

  • Mild cases: fever, headache, and malaise.
  • Severe cases: Fever, Severe headache, Seizures, Altered mental status (confusion, agitation, delirium), Neck stiffness, Paralysis (especially of the limbs)

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Serology: Detection of IgM antibodies against JEV in serum or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) (main)
  • PCR: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can detect JEV RNA in CSF or blood, typically within the first 5-7 days of infection

Treatment

  • Supportive Care: There is no specific antiviral treatment for JE.

Prevention

  • Vaccination:
    • Previously, the live attenuated strain SA 14-14-2 was used for vaccination in the national immunisation schedule
    • Now killed strain Kolar is used, given as 0.5 ml intramuscular

choices.text: 1-site IM vaccine given on days 0, 3, 7 and the fourth dose between days 14 to 28.
2-site IM vaccine given on day 0 and 1-site IM on days 7 and 21
2-site ID vaccine given on days 0 and 7
2-site ID vaccine is given on days 0, 3 and 7

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with complaints of difficulty in swallowing liquids, loss of appetite and restlessness. His history is significant for a dog bite a week ago. A brain biopsy of a patient is shown below. Which of the following schedules is not a part of the PEP regimen for this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The photo shows Negri bodies( intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion with characteristic basophilic inner granules, composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA), which are characteristic of Rabies infection.
  • Management of Animal bites is done based on the Degree of Bite:

There are various vaccination schedules for Rabies:

  • For post-exposure prophylaxis:
    • ID regimens are cost-effective, dose-sparing and time-sparing and therefore are preferred over IM regimens
      • ID regimen is known as the Thai regimen.
      • 2 site ID given on 0, 3, 7 +/- 28
    • IM regimen:
      • Essen regimen: 1 site IM given on 0, 3, 7, 14, 28
      • Zareb regimen: 2-site IM vaccine given on day 0, and 1 site IM on days 7 and 21.
  • PEP for Individuals Previously Vaccinated (PrEP or PEP):
    • 1 site ID vaccine given on days 0 and 3 or
    • 1 site IM vaccine given on days 0 and 3 or
    • 4 site ID vaccine given on day 0 only (left and right deltoids, thigh or suprascapular areas).
  • If re-exposure occurs within 3 months of receiving PEP, only local wound treatment is required; neither vaccine nor RIG are needed.
  • Pre-exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP):
    • 2 site ID vaccine given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28
    • 1 site IM vaccine given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28

questions.text:
Human herpes virus 4 is associated with many other diseases. From the following list, which is not associated with?
1) A teenager having kissing disease
2) Duncan syndrome in an 8-year-old boy
3) A 64-year-old male with Kaposi's sarcoma
4) A chronic tobacco chewer with oral submucous fibrosis
5) A HIV positive man with hairy leukoplakia
6) A 47-year-old female with cervical cancer
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Herpes virus 4 is also known as Epstein-Barr virus.
  • Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) causes Infectious mononucleosis / kissing disease and is also associated with several human tumours, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's disease, and B-cell lymphoma.

Other associations

  • Lymphoproliferative disorder: It is seen among immunodeficient patients, e.g. Duncan syndrome, which is an X-linked recessive disease affecting young boys.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia: Wart-like growth of epithelial cells of the tongue developed in some HIV-infected patients and transplant recipients.

choices.text: Coronaviruses enter the gastrointestinal tract through the mouth and move into the stomach, where they proliferate within mucosal cells to produce peptic ulcers.
Enteroviruses enter through the mouth, replicate in the pharynx and bowel, and move via the blood to distant target organs (central nervous system).
HIV is directly injected into the bloodstream by insects requiring blood for egg development.
Influenza viruses enter through the respiratory tract, replicate within lymphocytes in the lung.

questions.text: Viruses have various ways of entering the human body and producing disease. Which of the following descriptions accurately describes the route and mechanism for the virus indicated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Direct or indirect faecal oral transmission is considered the most common mode of spread of enterovirus.
  • After infection, the virus persists in the oropharynx for 1 to 4 weeks, and it can be shed in the faeces for 1 to 18 weeks.
  • The virus is present in respiratory secretions, including saliva, sputum, nasal mucous, and blister fluid,s as well as the stool of infected people.
  • Thus, sewage-contaminated water, fecally contaminated foods, or passive transmission by insect vectors (flies, cockroaches) may occasionally be the source of infection.
  • More commonly, however, the spread is directly from person to person.
  • This mode of transmission is suggested by the high infection rates seen among young children, whose hygienic practices tend to be less than optimal, and in crowded households.

Explanation of other options:

Coronaviruses enter the gastrointestinal tract through the mouth and move into the stomach, where they proliferate within mucosal cells to produce peptic ulcers (Option A): Viruses such as SARS-CoV-2 primarily enter the body through the respiratory tract (via inhalation of droplets or aerosols). They infect respiratory epithelial cells and type 2 pneumocytes. They enter via ACE-2 receptors.

HIV is directly injected into the bloodstream by insects requiring blood for egg development (Option C): HIV is not transmitted by insects. It is primarily transmitted through blood, semen, vaginal fluids, and breast milk. The main routes of transmission include sexual contact, sharing of needles, and mother-to-child transmission.

Influenza viruses enter through the respiratory tract, replicate within lymphocytes in the lung (Option D): Influenza viruses enter the body through the respiratory tract and replicate in the upper and lower respiratory epithelium; they do not replicate in lymphocytes. The systemic symptoms of muscle aches, fever, and stiff joints (myalgia, fever, arthralgia) seen in influenza infection are likely due to the immune response (e.g., cytokine release) rather than virus spreading via lymphatic vessels.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female HIV patient complains of pain during swallowing. There is a burning sensation every time she swallows. On examination, creamy white patches were seen on the oral mucosa. The test shown in the photo was positive. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above picture shows the Germ tube test, which is a confirmatory test for Albicans. A history of a white patch in the mouth for an immunocompromised patient suggests Oropharyngeal Candidiasis / Oral Thrush.
  • Candida albicans, if incubated in rabbit serum at 37°Cfor 2-4 hours, will produce germ tubes, which are short, unbranched filaments that sprout from the yeast cells. This is known as the Raynolds-Bradue phenomenon. This helps to differentiate albicans from the rest other subspecies.
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush): It presents as white, adherent, painless patches in the mouth.

Tests for species identification:

  • Germ tube test (positive for C. albicans)
  • Dalmau plate culture
  • CHROMagar
  • Molecular methods such as PCR

Other manifestations of Candida

  • Vulvovaginitis: It is characterised by pruritus, pain, and vaginal discharge that is usually thin, but may become whitish curd-like in severe cases.
  • Balanitis and balanoposthitis (occurring in uncircumcised males).
  • Oesophageal candidiasis.
  • Angular stomatitis and denture stomatitis.
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis: It is seen in infants and children with deficient CMI (T cell defect).
  • Cutaneous Candidiasis: The following cutaneous manifestations are produced in candidiasis:
    • Intertrigo: It is characterised by erythema and pustules in the skin folds; associated with tight-fitting undergarments and sweating.
    • Paronychia(involving nail-skin interface) and onychomycosis (fungal infection of nail).
    • Diaper candidiasis: Pustular rashes associated with the use of diapers in infants.
    • Perianal candidiasis.
  • Allergic Candidiasis. Various allergic manifestations seen in candidiasis include:
    • Candidid: This is an allergic reaction to the metabolites of Candida, characterised by vesicular lesions in the web space of hands and other areas, similar to that of dermatophytid reaction (both conditions are together called 'id' reaction).

Explanation of other options

Candida glabrata (Option B), Candida parapsilosis (Option C), Candida tropicalis (Option D): These Candida species are opportunistic fungal pathogens that can lead to Candidemia, UTI, Genital infection, and rarely Oral thrush.

choices.text: Orbital cellulitis; Antibiotics and supportive therapy

questions.text: A 65-year-old female diagnosed with COVID-19 was admitted with complaints of shortness of breath for 3 days. Her vitals were: BP: 156/108mmHg, SpO2: 88%, PR: 98/min and temp: 101.8°F. The patient has a history of diabetes. On the 10th day of her admission, she noticed sudden blackening of skin near the nose and eye, purulent discharge from the nose, and facial swelling. On nasal examination, a black necrotic mass was seen occupying the nasal cavity. What is the diagnosis and management in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • History of COVID infection and ICU admission suggests that she might have been on Steroids and on Ventilator support.
  • A black necrotic mass on the Nose, Facial swelling and purulent discharge suggest a diagnosis of Mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis:

  • Mucormycosis is a life-threatening fungal infection caused by moulds of the order Mucorales (e.g., Rhizopus, Mucor, Lichtheimia).
  • It is angioinvasive, leading to tissue necrosis and high mortality.
  • Confirmation of diagnosis is made bybiopsy (Gold standard) taken from the infected site. HPE shows broad hyphae, which are aseptate and branching at an obtuse angle.
  • Direct microscopy
    • KOH Mount/Gram Stain:- Broad, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphae (90° branching)
  • Culture
    • Sabouraud dextrose agar (grows rapidly, cottony colonies).
  • Treatment
    • Rapid surgical debridement is the mainstay of treatment because it can rapidly progress to invade the CNS through the cribriform plate.
    • Medical treatment: Liposomal amphotericin B.

Risk factors for mucormycosis

  • Diabetes (DKA)
  • Iron overload
  • Acidosis (metabolic)
  • Burns/trauma
  • Elevated steroids (COVID-19)
  • Transplant/neutropenia
  • IV drug use
  • Cancer (hematologic)

Histological appearance of Mucormycosis:

Explanation of other options:

Orbital cellulitis; Antibiotics and supportive therapy (Option A): Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the tissues around the eye, but it does not typically cause the necrotic, black lesions seen in this case. Orbital cellulitis requires antibiotics, but the patient's symptoms and findings are more consistent with mucormycosis than cellulitis.

Cutaneous anthrax; Doxycycline and ciprofloxacin (Option B): Anthrax presents as a necrotic lesion, usually associated with a painless ulcer with a black centre, and is not typically associated with sinus involvement or purulent discharge from the nose. The clinical picture does not match anthrax.

Extranodal T-cell lymphoma; Chemotherapy (Option D): Lymphoma can present with swelling and facial changes, but it is unlikely to cause a black necrotic mass in the nasal cavity, and it is not associated with purulent discharge. Lymphoma would typically require chemotherapy, but the clinical scenario points toward a fungal infection rather than a malignancy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male working as a gardener complains of painful nodules with purulent discharge on his arm and swollen lymph nodes in the axilla. He gave a history of a thorn prick 1 week back. What could be the probable diagnosis and its drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sporotrichosis or Rose Gardener's disease is presented as subcutaneous nodulo-ulcerative lesions, caused by a thermally dimorphic fungus, Sporothrix schenckii.
  • Noduloulcerative lesions (painless) occur along the lymphatics; called as sporotrichoid pattern of spread, which is also seen in other conditions.
  • Lymph nodes become enlarged, suppurative, indurated and have a cord-like feeling on palpation.
  • Specimens such as pus, aspirate from nodules, curettage or swabbing from ulcers are subjected to KOH mount or calcofluor staining, which demonstrate elongated yeast cells of 3-5 µm in diameter. But the sensitivity is very low.
  • Histopathological staining (e.g. hematoxylin and eosin) of tissue sections reveals cigar-shaped asteroid bodies.
  • The asteroid body consists of a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating extensions of eosinophilic mass, composed of antigen-antibody complexes. Such an eosinophilic halo is described as the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon, which is also observed in zygomycosis, candidiasis, aspergillosis and blastomycosis.

Culture:

  • Specimens are inoculated onto SDA and blood agar in duplicate and incubated at 25°C and 37°C simultaneously, because S. schenckii is a dimorphic fungus.
  • At 25°C, it produces mycelial form, consisting of slender, delicate hyphae with conidia arranged in a flower-like pattern.
  • At 37°C: It produces yeast form, characterised by moist creamy white colonies which turn brown black in 10-14 days.

Treatment:

  • Itraconazole is the drug of choice for all forms of sporotrichosis, except for the disseminated form, where amphotericin B is recommended.
  • Treatment is given until 2-4 weeks after the lesions resolve.

Sporothrix schenckii: Yeast form

Explanation of other options:

Rhinosporidium seeberii; Voriconazole (Option B): This organism causes rhinosporidiosis, a disease characterised by nasal masses. It is not associated with gardening injuries or thorn pricks.

A. flavus; Voriconazole: Aspergillus flavus (Option C) is a mould that typically causes invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised individuals, not a localised cutaneous infection. Voriconazole is used for Aspergillus infections, but this is not the correct organism for this scenario

C.albicans; Amphotericin B (Option D) usually presents as a localised infection with a white patch and itching. It doesn't cause tender nodules with purulent discharge at lymph nodes.

choices.text: a, b, c, d, e, f

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements for the disease shown in the photo.

a) Eumycetoma has a tumor which is single and has well defined margins.
b) Sinuses in actinomycetoma appear early with a raised, inflamed opening.
c) There is purulent discharge in eumycetoma.
d) The bone lesions in actinomycetoma are osteosclerotic.
e) Madurella mycetomatis produces black granules in eumycetoma.
f) Actinomadura pelletieri produces pink to red granules in actinomycetoma.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows a classic case of Mycetoma. 

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, progressive granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and bones.
  • Characterised by a triad of painless subcutaneous mass, sinus tracts and granular discharge (grains).
  • Types:
    • Eumycetoma (Fungal): Seen in Africa, Latin America.
    • Actinomycetoma (Bacterial): Seen in Mexico, India, and Sudan.

Clinical Presentation

  • Site: Feet (most common, ~70%), hands, back.
  • Progression:
    • Initial: Painless nodule after traumatic inoculation.
    • Advanced: Multiple sinus tracts discharging granules (white/yellow/black).
    • Late: Bone destruction, deformity, secondary bacterial infections.

Diagnosis:

  • Microscopy: KOH mount/Gram stain of discharge:
    • Eumycetoma: Broad fungal hyphae (black/white grains).
    • Actinomycetoma: Filamentous bacteria (fine, branching filaments).
  • Culture: Sabouraud dextrose agar (fungi) / Blood agar (bacteria).
  • Histopathology: Granulomas with grains (hematoxylin & eosin/GMS stain).

questions.text: A previously well 9-year-old boy presented to the clinic with a tender, swollen occipital scalp lesion progressing over one month's duration. He was initially misdiagnosed as having a bacterial infection and was given a 2-week course of oral cephalexin. No improvement was noticed after the course. It was only after the scalp scrapings were examined that the child was found to have a local infection with the fungus, as shown in the photo. Identify the causative organism, and what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history and image led to a diagnosis of Kerion.

  • A kerion is a severe, inflamed, and painful form of tinea capitis, characterised by an abscess-like presentation with painful boggy swelling, pus, and often hair loss in the affected area.
  • Caused by Trichophyton mentagrophytes, T. verrucosum.
  • Hair perforation test is positive.

Explanation of other options:

Favus; Trichophyton schoenleinii (Option A): Hallmark feature of favus is the formation of scaly, yellowish crusts (called scutula). It is caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.

Ectothrix; Microsporum canis (Option B): Fungi infect the outside of the hair shaft and cause a grey patch type tinea capitis. Commonly caused by Microsporum canis.

Endothrix; Trichophyton tonsurans (Option C): Fungi infect the inside of the hair shaft; hair breaks at the scalp surface, giving the black dot sign. Caused by Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum.

questions.text: A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the pediatric clinic with a history of jaundice, microcephaly, and a petechial rash since birth. On examination, the baby has hepatosplenomegaly and a reduced level of alertness. A cranial ultrasound reveals periventricular calcifications, and an eye exam shows chorioretinitis. The mother had a history of fever and sore throat during pregnancy, but no history of recent vaccinations or known infections. What is the most likely cause of the newborn's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common viral cause of congenital infections.
  • It can present with a range of symptoms such as
    • Hepatosplenomegaly (Most common)
    • Petechial lesions (blueberry muffin)
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Calcification (Periventricular calcification)
    • Convulsions
    • Microcephaly/ Macrocephaly
    • Mental retardation
  • One of the hallmark features of congenital CMV is the presence of periventricular calcifications and chorioretinitis, which are seen on imaging and ophthalmologic examination.
  • The mother's history of fever and sore throat during pregnancy suggests a possible primary CMV infection, which is a significant risk factor for congenital CMV transmission.
  • Lab diagnosis:
    • PCR for CMV DNA
    • ELISA for antigen detection
    • Immunofluorescence-based methods
    • Shell vial technique to culture CMV

Explanation of other options:

Rubella virus infection (Option A): Rubella causes congenital defects like cataracts, heart defects, and sensorineural hearing loss, but periventricular calcifications and chorioretinitis are not typically associated with rubella. Additionally, rubella is largely preventable through vaccination.

Toxoplasma gondii infection (Option C): While toxoplasmosis can cause intracranial calcifications and chorioretinitis, it would typically present with hydrocephalus and intracranial calcifications (not periventricular), hydrocephalus and chorioretinitis.

Herpes simplex virus infection (Option D): Neonatal HSV typically presents with skin lesions, and while it can cause neurodevelopmental delays and encephalitis.

questions.text: A 28-week preterm baby was born with a weight of 1.5kg, a cicatricial skin lesion and limb hypoplasia. The infant had an episode of seizure after 5 hours of being born. On USG, the kidneys were enlarged, suggestive of hydronephrosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clinical history and findings are suggestive of Congenital varicella syndrome, caused by Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which is highly teratogenic. The risk of transmission is maximum when the mother acquires primary infection during early pregnancy.

Congenital varicella syndrome is characterised by:

  • Cicatricial skin lesions and limb hypoplasia (most characteristic anomalies).
  • CNS defects: Microcephaly, mental disability and seizures.
  • Ocular defects: Chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, and cataract.
  • Renal system defects: Hydroureter and hydronephrosis.
  • Autonomic system defect: Neurogenic bladder.
  • Low birth weight.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital Zika syndrome (Option B): Presents with severe microcephaly, intracranial calcifications, ocular abnormalities, and joint contractures, not cicatricial skin lesions or limb hypoplasia.

Congenital syphilis (Option C):

  • Earliest manifestations occur within 2 years of age.
  • Affected children are infectious and they suffer from rhinitis (or snuffles), mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy.
  • Late congenital syphilis occurs after 2 years and is noninfectious. It is characterised by interstitial keratitis, eighth nerve deafness, and bilateral knee effusions (Clutton's joints).
  • Residual stigmata may remain for a long time, such as Hutchinson's teeth (notched central incisors), Mulberry molars (molars with poorly developed cusps), Saddle nose, and sabre shins.

Congenital trypanosomiasis (Option D):

  • Presents with Prematurity, Low birth weight, Hepatosplenomegaly, or is asymptomatic at birth.
  • May lead to Stillbirth
  • Severe cases can lead to Meningoencephalitis, Myocarditis

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a rash that started behind the ears and spread to the rest of the body. On examination, bluish-white spots are seen on the buccal mucosa. What is the most likely clinical diagnosis, and which type of cells are found in the lesions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history is suggestive of Measles, characterised by Bluish-white spots with pathognomic Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.

  • Measles is caused by the measles virus, the Paramyxoviridae family.

Clinical Features of Measles

  • Prodrome (Initial Phase): This phase typically lasts 2-4 days and is characterised by:
    • Fever
    • Cough
    • Coryza (runny nose)
    • Conjunctivitis (red, watery eyes)
    • Koplik spots: These are small, bluish-white spots seen on the buccal mucosa (inner cheeks), usually opposite the molars, and are pathognomonic for measles.
  • Rash Phase: The rash typically appears on the 3rd to 5th day of illness and has the following progression:
    • Starts behind the ears and along the hairline.
    • Spreads downward to the face, neck, trunk, arms, and legs.
    • The rash is maculopapular (flat and raised red spots).
    • The rash usually lasts 5-6 days before fading, and the fever typically subsides as the rash appears.
  • Post-rash Recovery Phase:
    • The rash fades in the order of its appearance.
    • Patients begin to improve, but fatigue and cough can persist for some time.

Complications of Measles: Measles can lead to serious complications, particularly in young children, immunocompromised patients, and adults. These include:

  • Pneumonia(the most common cause of death from measles)
  • Encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can cause permanent neurological damage)
  • Otitis media (most common complication)
  • Diarrhea
  • Keratitis and blindness
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE): A rare but fatal complication that occurs nearly 10 years after infection, leading to progressive neurological deterioration.

Explanation of other options:

Measles; Physiological giant cell (Option A): These are multinucleated giant cells, normal in certain developmental stages.

HZV; Touton giant cell (Option B): Touton giant cells are seen in lipid-related disorders like xanthomas, not viral infections.

HZV; Langhans giant cells (Option D): Langhans giant cells are found in granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis, sarcoidosis and not in measles or HZV infections.

Types of giant cells

questions.text: Which serotype of HPV results in the following disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above image shows plantar warts, caused by HPV serotype 1.

HPV 1-4, 7, 10 have been implicated in:

  • Common hand warts
  • Plantar warts
  • Flat cutaneous warts of other skin areas

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presented with a history of loss of appetite, malaise and jaundice of 4 months duration. On examination, there was icterus, hepatomegaly and tenderness in the right hypochondriac region. He had a history of blood transfusions when he met with an accident 6 months ago. On laboratory examination, he was found to be positive for HBsAg. What is the genome of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Positive for HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) indicates an active infection with the Hepatitis B virus, which is consistent with the patient's symptoms of malaise, loss of appetite, jaundice, and hepatomegaly.

  • HBV has a unique genome structure composed of partially double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).
  • The genome consists of a short partially double-stranded region and a longer single-stranded region.
  • This is different from many other DNA viruses, which have fully double-stranded or fully single-stranded genomes.
  • The partially double-stranded nature of the HBV genome is important in its replication and reverse transcription processes, as the single-stranded portion is converted into double-stranded DNA after infection of the host cell.

questions.text: A group of patients presented to the emergency department with chief complaints of fever, vomiting and diarrhoea. All of them had attended a birthday party 4-6 hours back, where they had Subway sandwiches and pastries. What is your probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning.
  • Staphylococcus aureus is often found in dairy products, pastries, meats, and sandwiches that are improperly stored or handled, especially foods prepared in advance (which may be the case with sandwiches and pastries at a party).
  • These foods can become contaminated with S. aureus, and the bacteria can produce enterotoxins that cause the rapid onset of symptoms.
  • Causative Toxin:
    • Heat-stable enterotoxins (A-E, G-I) are produced by S. aureus in contaminated food.
    • Toxins are pre-formed in food (not damaged by reheating).
  • Incubation Period:
    • Rapid onset (1–6 hours) after ingestion.
  • Symptoms:
    • Severe vomiting (most prominent symptom).
    • Nausea, abdominal cramps.
    • Diarrhoea (less common, may occur later).
  • Common Food Sources:
    • Dairy products (custards, pastries, milk).
    • Processed meats..
    • Leftovers were improperly stored at room temperature.

Explanation of other options:

Bacillus cereus food poisoning (Option A): These are commonly associated with Chinese fast food, especially fried rice. This bacterium produces two types of toxins that cause food poisoning:

  • Cereulide(Emetic)toxin - This toxin causes vomiting, typically within 1-6 hours after consumption of contaminated food.
  • Enterotoxin (Diarrhoeal) toxin - This toxin causes watery diarrhoea and abdominal cramps, and symptoms usually develop 8-16 hours after ingestion.

Clostridium perfringens food poisoning (Option B): C. perfringens-associated food poisoning typically has a delayed onset (8-16 hours). It's associated with foods like meat, poultry, and gravy that are undercooked or left at room temperature.

Vibrio cholera food poisoning (Option D): Vibrio cholerae typically causes severe watery diarrhoea (rice-water stool) and is associated with contaminated water or seafood. The onset is usually 12-72 hours.

choices.text: The baby is at high risk for congenital syphilis
The mother needs a lumbar puncture and a VDRL test for her CSF for neurosyphilis
The mother needs to be treated again for syphilis
The mother's previous treatment for syphilis was effective

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman who is 10 weeks pregnant presents to the Obstetrics clinic for prenatal care. She has a history of treatment for syphilis 4 years previously. The results of serologic tests for syphilis are as follows:
Non-treponemal test RPR: Non-Reactive
Treponemal test (TP-PA): Reactive
Which of the following statements is most correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Non-treponemal test (RPR) (Non-Reactive): This test measures antibodies that are produced in response to syphilis, but it is non-specific and can remain negative if the patient was treated and has no active infection.
  • Treponemal test (TP-PA) (Reactive): This test detects antibodies specifically against Treponema pallidum, the bacterium that causes syphilis. A positive result indicates previous exposure to syphilis, even if the person is no longer infected.
  • This indicates that the treatment was effective (Option C ruled out).

Explanation of other options:

The baby is at high risk for congenital syphilis (Option A): A non-reactive RPR typically suggests no active infection, and therefore, the risk of congenital syphilis is not elevated.

The mother needs a lumbar puncture and a VDRL test for her CSF for neurosyphilis (Option B): There is no indication of neurosyphilis in this case. The mother is asymptomatic, and the test results do not suggest the need for further investigation into neurosyphilis, as she has no clinical signs or symptoms.

choices.text: A 25-year-old male complaining of blood in stools and increased frequency for 3 days.
A 4-year-old child complaining of watery diarrhoea, without signs of dehydration
an immunocompromised female presenting with watery diarrhoea
30-year-old male complaining of fever and diarrhoea following travelling for pilgrimage.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions doesn't require stool examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stool examination is not required in cases of mild watery diarrhoea without signs of dehydration.

Stool examination is required when,

  • Bloody diarrhoea (Dysentery) (Option A ruled out)
  • Watery diarrhoea with dehydration
  • Severe or Prolonged diarrhoea for > 72 hours
  • Severe Gastrointestinal Symptoms:
  • Recent Travel History (Option D ruled out)
  • Recent Use of Antibiotics
  • HIV or Immunocompromised Patients (Option C ruled out)

Stool culture: Stool specimens should be transported within 1 hour, but with transport medium (Cary-Blair medium) up to 24 hours is acceptable.

choices.text: Crystal violet (1 min) → Gram's iodine (1 min) → acetone (2-3 seconds) → safranin (30 seconds)
Crystal violet (1 min) → Gram's iodine (2 mins) → acetone (20-30 seconds) → safranin (30 seconds)
Gram's iodine (2 mins) → Crystal violet (1 min) → acetone (20-30 seconds) → safranin (30 seconds)
Crystal violet (1 min) → Gram's iodine (1 min) → acetone (2-3 seconds) → basic fuchsin (2 mins)

questions.text: What is the correct order for Gram staining?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The smear is examined under an oil immersion objective:

  • Gram-positive bacteria resist decolourisation and retain the colour of the primary stain, i.e. violet.
  • Gram-negative bacteria are decolourised and, therefore, take counterstain and appear pink.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient presented with a history of eating outside. After 48 h, he had a sudden onset of painless watery diarrhoea that quickly became voluminous and was followed by vomiting. His skin became pale yellow, and he became weak from loose motions and vomiting. He experienced abdominal cramps, and fever was typically absent. The stool collected had a watery rice appearance. Identify the aetiology and its suitable transport media.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rice water stools are pathognomonic of Cholera.
  • Vibrio choleraeis a gram-negative bacterium that produces cholera toxin, leading to profuse watery diarrhoea due to electrolyte imbalance and loss of water from the intestines.
  • Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan medium is a special transport medium used to transport stool specimens suspected to contain Vibrio cholerae.

Explanation of other options:

Salmonella typhi; Cary Blair medium (Option A): Salmonella Typhi causes typhoid fever usually presents with fever, abdominal pain, constipation or diarrhoea. Cary- Blair medium is used as the transport medium for this organism.

Shigella; Buffered glycerol saline (Option B): Shigella causes dysentery (bloody diarrhoea with fever and tenesmus). The transport medium for Shigella is buffered glycerol saline.

Neisseria; Stuart's media (Option C), such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Neisseria meningitidis, do not cause watery diarrhoea. Stuart's media is used as a transport medium.

questions.text: A microbiologist is about to run a polymerase chain reaction assay on the specimen of a patient suspected of having TB. He wishes to ensure specificity by using 2 sets of primers. Which of the following PCRs should he perform?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nested PCR involves two rounds of amplification with two sets of primers.

  • The first set of primers amplifies a larger region of DNA.
  • After the first amplification, a second set of primers, which are "nested" within the region amplified by the first set, is used to amplify a smaller region.
  • This approach increases the specificity and sensitivity of the PCR because the second round of amplification is highly specific, reducing the chances of non-specific binding from the first round.

Indications:

  • High-sensitivity detection of low-abundance targets (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis in paucibacillary samples).
  • Reducing contamination risk in two-step amplification.
  • Sequencing confirmation (e.g., HIV drug resistance testing).

Explanation of other options:

Multiplex PCR (Option A): Multiplex PCR uses multiple primers in a single reaction to amplify different target sequences simultaneously.

Real-time PCR (Option C): Also called quantitative PCR or qPCR, is used for quantifying the amount of target DNA in real-time as the PCR progresses.

Reverse Transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) (Option D): RT-PCR is used to detect and quantify RNA by first converting it to complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase.
